summary: This is an email chain from December 2018 among Assistant United States Attorneys in the Southern District of New York discussing a hate crimes brainstorming session. In a forwarded message, one attorney mentions being added to the Epstein investigation, noting that 'the brass approved moving forward with an investigation' and that it's 'good for the HT role.'

persons.name: Blain
persons.role: Assistant United States Attorney, Co-Chief of Civil Rights Unit
persons.context: Initiates the email chain about organizing a hate crimes brainstorming session with FBI and NYPD, and signs as Co-Chief of the Civil Rights Unit.

persons.name: Kennedy
persons.context: Listed as a recipient of the initial email about the hate crimes brainstorming session.

connections.description: Both are Assistant United States Attorneys in the Southern District of New York, collaborating on organizing a hate crimes brainstorming session.

events.title: Hate crimes meeting proposal
events.description: Blain emails colleagues to propose reaching out to FBI and NYPD Hate Crimes Task Force to set up a meeting about hate crimes cases.

events.title: Epstein investigation approval noted
events.description: In a forwarded email, an attorney states they 'got added to the Epstein investigation' and that 'the brass approved moving forward with an investigation,' suggesting it's good for their Human Trafficking (HT) role.

locations: 86 Chambers Street, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: An attorney in the Southern District of New York mentions being added to the Epstein investigation in a December 2018 email.
The email states 'the brass approved moving forward with an investigation' regarding Epstein.
The attorney suggests the Epstein investigation is 'good for the HT [Human Trafficking] role,' linking it to human trafficking concerns.
The primary context of the email chain is planning a hate crimes brainstorming session with FBI and NYPD.
The document shows internal DOJ communication where the Epstein investigation is mentioned incidentally alongside other criminal justice priorities.
